It might be useful to split this component into two: <code>ThoughtList.vue</code> and <code>ThoughtItem.vue</code>.</p> <p>So, we'll change <code>src/ThoughtList.vue</code> to:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-html"><code><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>script</span> <span class="token attr-name">setup</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><span class="token script"><span class="token language-javascript"> <span class="token keyword module">import</span> <span class="token imports"><span class="token punctuation">{</span> ref <span class="token punctuation">}</span></span> <span class="token keyword module">from</span> <span class="token string">'vue'</span> <span class="token keyword module">import</span> <span class="token imports"><span class="token maybe-class-name">ThoughtItem</span></span> <span class="token keyword module">from</span> <span class="token string">'./ThoughtItem.vue'</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> items <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">ref</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'hello'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'world!'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> </span></span><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>script</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span>
<span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>ul</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>li</span> <span class="token attr-name">v-for</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>item in items<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>ThoughtItem</span> <span class="token punctuation">/></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>li</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>ul</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> </code></pre></div> <p>and the new <code>ThoughtItem.vue</code> will contain:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-html"><code><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>p</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> Hello world! <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>p</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> </code></pre></div> <p>And of course, don't forget to add it to <code>App.vue</code>:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-html"><code><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>script</span> <span class="token attr-name">setup</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><span class="token script"><span class="token language-javascript"> <span class="token keyword module">import</span> <span class="token imports"><span class="token maybe-class-name">ThoughtList</span></span> <span class="token keyword module">from</span> <span class="token string">"./components/ThoughtList.vue"</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> </span></span><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>script</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span>
<span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>main</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>ThoughtList</span> <span class="token punctuation">/></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>main</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> </code></pre></div> <h3 id="passing-text-from-parent-to-child"><a href="#passing-text-from-parent-to-child" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Passing text from parent to child</h3> <p>We've seen how to trigger events from child to parent, and now, it's time to <em>flip</em> that formula around.</p> <p>Currently, our <code>ThoughtItem</code> displays the same text: "Hello world!"</p> <p>But we want to show real data, which is held by the parent <code>ThoughtList</code> in the <code>items</code> reactive variable.</p> <p>The solution to this problem is called <strong>Props</strong> (properties). They're like HTML attributes, if they could contain <em>anything</em>! (arrays, objects, and even functions!)</p> <p>So let's make a little change to <code>ThoughtList.vue</code>:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-html"><code><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>ul</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>li</span> <span class="token attr-name">v-for</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>item in items<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>ThoughtItem</span> <span class="token attr-name">:message</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>item<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span> <span class="token punctuation">/></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>li</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>ul</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> </code></pre></div> <p>Hey! It's important to add the colon : before the prop name. It tells Vue to treat the content between "..." as JavaScript code (the item variable), instead of a String (the text "item").</p> <p>And now, we can access the text message in <code>ThoughtItem</code> effortlessly:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-html"><code><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>script</span> <span class="token attr-name">setup</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><span class="token script"><span class="token language-javascript"> <span class="token function">defineProps</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token literal-property property">message</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token known-class-name class-name">String</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token comment">// `message` has type String.</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> </span></span><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>script</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span>
<span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>p</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> {{ message }} <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>p</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> </code></pre></div> <p>Hey! Just like defineEmits, defineProps is a compiler macro and doesn't require importing.</p> <h3 id="loading-data-from-the-server"><a href="#loading-data-from-the-server" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Loading data from the server</h3> <p>Up until now, we only used mock data. So, let's change that! We'll be getting data from an external API.</p> <p>But first, notice that we'll need to access our API from two separate components: ThoughtList for retrieving all items, and NewModal for adding new items to the <a href="https://docs.cyclic.sh/docs/concepts/database" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">l</a>ist.</p> <p>This is called a <a href="https://vuejs.org/guide/scaling-up/state-management.html#what-is-state-management" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">shared-state</a> between multiple components. There's no immediately obvious way of solving this issue, but thankfully, there's an entire library designed just for that, and it's called <a href="https://pinia.vuejs.org/" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Pinia</a>.</p> <p>This is where we'll start working with the stores/ folder. So let's create the src/stores/thoughts.js file.</p> <p></p> <p><img alt="" src="/content/62e02ef269d01d02c0b009f1_pinia.png"></p> <p></p> <p>A store should always resemble this boilerplate, so use it as a starting-point:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-javascript"><code><span class="token comment">// thoughts.js</span> <span class="token keyword module">import</span> <span class="token imports"><span class="token punctuation">{</span> defineStore <span class="token punctuation">}</span></span> <span class="token keyword module">from</span> <span class="token string">'pinia'</span>
<span class="token keyword module">export</span> <span class="token keyword module">default</span> <span class="token function">defineStore</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'thoughts'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token function-variable function">state</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token arrow operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token comment">// Reactive variables here</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token literal-property property">actions</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token comment">// Methods here</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> </code></pre></div> <p>We created a store with the "thoughts" ID name.</p> <p>But <em>what</em> is a store, you may ask? It's simply a collection of reactive variables and methods that act on them:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-javascript"><code><span class="token comment">// thoughts.js</span> <span class="token keyword module">import</span> <span class="token imports"><span class="token punctuation">{</span> defineStore <span class="token punctuation">}</span></span> <span class="token keyword module">from</span> <span class="token string">'pinia'</span>
<span class="token keyword module">export</span> <span class="token keyword module">default</span> <span class="token function">defineStore</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'thoughts'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token function">state</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token keyword control-flow">return</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token literal-property property">reactive_var</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token literal-property property">another_reactive_var</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'awesome!'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token literal-property property">again_another_reactive_var</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">0</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">4</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token literal-property property">actions</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token function">my_method</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token comment">// We can access all reactive variables here using `this.`</span> <span class="token comment">// NOTE: we don't have to use `.value` here!</span> <span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token property-access">reactive_var</span><span class="token operator">++</span> <span class="token keyword control-flow">return</span> <span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token property-access">another_reactive_var</span> <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token number">4.5</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> </code></pre></div> <p>Notice how we don't have to use .value here. Awesome!</p> <p>Now, let's create an actually useful store:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-javascript"><code><span class="token comment">// thoughts.js</span> <span class="token keyword module">import</span> <span class="token imports"><span class="token punctuation">{</span> defineStore <span class="token punctuation">}</span></span> <span class="token keyword module">from</span> <span class="token string">"pinia"</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span>
<span class="token keyword module">export</span> <span class="token keyword module">default</span> <span class="token function">defineStore</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">"thoughts"</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token function">state</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token keyword control-flow">return</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token literal-property property">items</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token literal-property property">actions</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token keyword">async</span> <span class="token function">load</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token comment">// Fetch data from the Cyclic API</span> <span class="token keyword">const</span> res <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword control-flow">await</span> <span class="token function">fetch</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">"https://ithink-api.cyclic.app/"</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token literal-property property">headers</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token string-property property">"Content-Type"</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">"application/json"</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> <span class="token keyword">const</span> items <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword control-flow">await</span> res<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token method function property-access">json</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span>
<span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token property-access">items</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> items<span class="token punctuation">;</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token keyword">async</span> <span class="token function">add</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">message</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token comment">// Post data to the Cyclic API</span> <span class="token keyword control-flow">await</span> <span class="token function">fetch</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">"https://ithink-api.cyclic.app/"</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token literal-property property">method</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">"post"</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token literal-property property">headers</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token string-property property">"Content-Type"</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">"application/json"</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token literal-property property">body</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token known-class-name class-name">JSON</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token method function property-access">stringify</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token literal-property property">text</span><span class="token operator">:</span> message<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span>
<span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token property-access">items</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token method function property-access">unshift</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>message<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> </code></pre></div> <p>All we did here is declare an items reactive variable that will contain our most important data. We then defined the load method that should be called to load data from the server and assign it to items.</p> <p>We also defined the add action, which asynchronously sends data to the server and adds it to the items list.</p> <h3 id="using-real-data-in-our-application"><a href="#using-real-data-in-our-application" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Using real data in our application</h3> <p></p><p data-height="600" data-default-tab="js,result" data-slug-hash="BarKXOy" data-preview="true" data-user="eludapens" class="codepen" style="height:600px;box-sizing:border-box;display:flex;align-items:center;justify-content:center;border:2px solid;margin:1em 0;padding:1em"> <span>See the Pen <a href="https://codepen.io/eludapens/pen/BarKXOy"> It's Twitter, but you can't delete.</a> by Eluda (<a href="https://codepen.io/eludapens">@eludapens</a>) on <a href="https://codepen.io">CodePen</a>.</span></p> <p></p> <script async src="https://cpwebassets.codepen.io/assets/embed/ei.js"></script> <p>Let's connect our thoughts store with our application! We'll start with NewModal:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-html"><code><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>script</span> <span class="token attr-name">setup</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><span class="token script"><span class="token language-javascript"> <span class="token keyword module">import</span> <span class="token imports">getThoughtsStore</span> <span class="token keyword module">from</span> <span class="token string">'../stores/thoughts.js'</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token literal-property property">add</span><span class="token operator">:</span> addItem <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">getThoughtsStore</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token keyword">async</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">submit</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token keyword control-flow">await</span> <span class="token function">addItem</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>message<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token property-access">value</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token function">close</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span> </span></span><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>script</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> </code></pre></div> <p>We extracted the add function from the store by calling it as a function. Here, we called it getThoughtsStore, which is a convention when using Pinia.</p> <p>Would you believe me if I told you that was it? Well, I never lie.</p> <p>Let's move into ThoughtList, which will load data from the server in order to display it.</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-html"><code><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>script</span> <span class="token attr-name">setup</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><span class="token script"><span class="token language-javascript"> <span class="token keyword module">import</span> <span class="token imports">getThoughtsStore</span> <span class="token keyword module">from</span> <span class="token string">"../stores/thoughts"</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> <span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token literal-property property">load</span><span class="token operator">:</span> loadItems <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">getThoughtsStore</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span>
<span class="token keyword control-flow">await</span> <span class="token function">loadItems</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> </span></span><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>script</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> </code></pre></div> <p>And we also have to access the items reactive variable straight from the store. So let's follow the same pattern here:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-javascript"><code><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> items <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">getThoughtsStore</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> <span class="token comment">// this is WRONG</span> </code></pre></div> <p>But counter-intuitively, this breaks the reactivity of the variable. Here's the right way of doing this:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-javascript"><code><span class="token keyword module">import</span> <span class="token imports"><span class="token punctuation">{</span> storeToRefs <span class="token punctuation">}</span></span> <span class="token keyword module">from</span> <span class="token string">"pinia"</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> <span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> items <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">storeToRefs</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token function">getThoughtsStore</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> <span class="token comment">// CORRECT :)</span> </code></pre></div> <p>Perfect!</p> <p>Notice how in our previous code example, we're using a top-level await to load the data in ThoughtList:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-html"><code><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>script</span> <span class="token attr-name">setup</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><span class="token script"><span class="token language-javascript"> <span class="token keyword module">import</span> <span class="token imports">getThoughtsStore</span> <span class="token keyword module">from</span> <span class="token string">"@/stores/thoughts"</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> <span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token literal-property property">load</span><span class="token operator">:</span> loadItems <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">getThoughtsStore</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span>
<span class="token keyword control-flow">await</span> <span class="token function">loadItems</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> </span></span><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>script</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> </code></pre></div> <p>Components with <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46515764/how-can-i-use-async-await-at-the-top-level" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">top-level awaits</a> are called <strong>async components</strong>.</p> <p>If we leave it like this, we're gonna get the following error: (check your devtools console)</p> <p>Component <code><Anonymous></code>: setup function returned a promise, but no <code><Suspense></code> boundary was found in the parent component tree. A component with async setup() must be nested in a <code><Suspense></code> in order to be rendered.</p> <p>It's telling us that we should use a component called <code><Suspense></code> as a parent to the <a href="https://vuejs.org/guide/components/async.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank"><code>async component</code></a>. <a href="https://vuejs.org/guide/built-ins/suspense.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank"><code><Suspense></code></a> is a built-in Vue component, so we can use it anywhere in our app. Let's use it in App.vue:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-html"><code><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>script</span> <span class="token attr-name">setup</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><span class="token script"><span class="token language-javascript"> <span class="token keyword module">import</span> <span class="token imports"><span class="token maybe-class-name">ThoughtList</span></span> <span class="token keyword module">from</span> <span class="token string">"./components/ThoughtList.vue"</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> </span></span><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>script</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span>
<span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>main</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>Suspense</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>ThoughtList</span> <span class="token punctuation">/></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>Suspense</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>main</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> </code></pre></div> <p>It now works <em>perfectly</em>! Yay!</p> <h3 id="adding-a-loading-state-to-our-list"><a href="#adding-a-loading-state-to-our-list" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Adding a loading state to our list</h3> <p data-height="600" data-default-tab="js,result" data-slug-hash="gOerqjg" data-preview="true" data-user="eludapens" class="codepen" style="height:600px;box-sizing:border-box;display:flex;align-items:center;justify-content:center;border:2px solid;margin:1em 0;padding:1em"> <span>See the Pen <a href="https://codepen.io/eludapens/pen/gOerqjg"> It's Twitter, but you can't delete.</a> by Eluda (<a href="https://codepen.io/eludapens">@eludapens</a>) on <a href="https://codepen.io">CodePen</a>.</span> </p> <script async src="https://cpwebassets.codepen.io/assets/embed/ei.js"></script> <p>Currently, our ThoughtList component will be invisible until data is loaded. That's inconvenient, and makes a great example of <a href="https://pencilandpaper.io/articles/ux-pattern-analysis-loading-feedback/" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">bad UX</a>.</p> <p>Thankfully, since we're already using <code><Suspense></code>, we can directly tell it to show something else while its child is loading. Add this to App.vue:</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-html"><code><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>Suspense</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>ThoughtList</span> <span class="token punctuation">/></span></span>
<span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>template</span> <span class="token attr-name">#fallback</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>p</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span>Loading...<span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>p</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>Suspense</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> </code></pre></div> <p>As you can see, anything within <code><template #fallback></code> will be shown when ThoughtList is loading. Awesome!</p> <p>But we can get even awesome-r than that. Let's show a <a href="https://uxdesign.cc/what-you-should-know-about-skeleton-screens-a820c45a571a" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">loading skeleton</a>!</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="line-numbers language-html"><code><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>Suspense</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>ThoughtList</span> <span class="token punctuation">/></span></span>
<span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>template</span> <span class="token attr-name">#fallback</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>div</span> <span class="token attr-name">class</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>flex flex-wrap gap-2<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"><</span>div</span> <span class="token attr-name">v-for</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>i in 15<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span> <span class="token attr-name">class</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>h-16 w-48 animate-pulse rounded bg-stone-50/10<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>div</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>div</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>template</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation"></</span>Suspense</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span> </code></pre></div> <p>You should know that i in 15 is a shortcut that Vue offers us to loop over the range [1, , 15]. Super!</p> <p>And with that done, our app is now <strong>complete!</strong> Now that wasn't so hard, was it?</p> <h3 id="conclusion"><a href="#conclusion" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Conclusion</h3> <p>We covered a handy amount of Vue features:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://vuejs.org/guide/built-ins/suspense.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Suspense</a> and <a href="https://vuejs.org/guide/components/async.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">async components</a></li> <li><a href="https://vueuse.org/functions" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">The @vueuse library</a></li> <li><a href="https://vuejs.org/guide/essentials/reactivity-fundamentals.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Reactive variables</a></li> <li><a href="https://vuejs.org/guide/built-ins/suspense.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Skeleton loading</a></li> <li><a href="https://vuejs.org/guide/components/events.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Custom events</a></li> <li><a href="https://vuejs.org/guide/essentials/lifecycle.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Lifecycle hooks</a></li> <li><a href="https://vuejs.org/guide/essentials/template-refs.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Template refs</a></li> <li><a href="https://vuejs.org/guide/essentials/list.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">v-for</a> and <a href="https://vuejs.org/guide/essentials/conditional.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">v-if</a></li> <li><a href="https://pinia.vuejs.org/" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Pinia</a></li> </ul> <p>Some of these are common to all web frameworks, while some aren't. We'll compare Vue with the rest of its peers at the end of this series, so I suggest you keep on reading! Trust me, there's a whole lot more to learn! </p> <p></p></div></div></div></div></div> <section id="subscribe-form" class="subscribe-form wf-section"><div class="centered-container w-container"><h2>Subscribe to posts</h2> <p>Enter your email If you would like to get an email the next time we post.<br>We post about ~1-3x per month, and up to once a month about company news.<br></p></div> <div class="container-5 w-container"><div id="embedded-form"></div></div></section> <div class="banner wf-section"><div class="container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-center"><div class="column desk-12"><img src="/images/Rectangle-240-copy.svg" loading="lazy" alt class="absolute-image"> <div class="cta-box"><div class="text-box _600px"><h2>Launch a hello world</h2> <p>Fork and deploy a hello world project onto Cyclic faster than it has taken to read this page. Experience the power.</p> <div class="spacer _24"></div> <a href="https://app.cyclic.sh/api/login?utm_source=www&utm_medium=web&utm_campaign=cta" target="_blank" class="button white w-button">Deploy on Cyclic </a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div> <div class="footer wf-section"><div class="spacer _64"></div> <div class="footer-container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-top"><div class="column desk-6 tab-12"><a href="/" aria-current="page" data-ix="logo" class="footer-logo w-nav-brand w--current nuxt-link-active"><img src="/images/default-monochrome-white.svg" loading="lazy" alt="cyclic logo" class="image"></a> <p class="paragraph-small no-margin"> 2021-2022 <a href="/" aria-current="page" class="w--current">Cyclic Software</a><br></p> <div class="spacer _64"></div></div> item.title: We sound like idiots when we talk about technical debt

property="og:description" content="When we use the term technical debt with non-technical business colleagues, they assume, that technical debt is analogous to financial debt. After a few minutes of discussion they are usually relieved to find that there is no actual money problem. How quickly would the CFO get fired if they claimed &quot;we have a lot of debt&quot; but couldnt produce a balance sheet with lenders, amounts, interest rates and terms?"><meta data-n-head="ssr" data-hid="twitter:description" name="twitter:description" content="When we use the term technical debt with non-technical business colleagues, they assume, that technical debt is analogous to financial debt. After a few minutes of discussion they are usually relieved to find that there is no actual money problem. How quickly would the CFO get fired if they claimed &quot;we have a lot of debt&quot; but couldnt produce a balance sheet with lenders, amounts, interest rates and terms?"><meta data-n-head="ssr" data-hid="description" name="description" content="When we use the term technical debt with non-technical business colleagues, they assume, that technical debt is analogous to financial debt. After a few minutes of discussion they are usually relieved to find that there is no actual money problem. How quickly would the CFO get fired if they claimed &quot;we have a lot of debt&quot; but couldnt produce a balance sheet with lenders, amounts, interest rates and terms?"><meta data-n-head="ssr" data-w-id="cb94c0a0-2bab-b0c9-9da8-d93e4ab951f6" xstyle="opacity:0" class="blog-container w-container"><h1>We sound like idiots when we talk about technical debt</h1> <div class="byline"><div class="text-block-6">By:</div> <div><div class="text-block-6">Kam Lasater</div> <a href="https://twitter.com/@seekayel" class="link-2">@seekayel</a></div> <div class="div-block"></div> <div class="text-block-5">Posted: February 8, 2022</div></div> <div class="div-block-2"><a href="#" class="link-block w-inline-block w-clearfix"><div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div> <div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div></a></div> <div class="spacer _32"></div> <div class="rich-text w-richtext"><div class="nuxt-content"><h3 id="does-this-sound-familiar"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#does-this-sound-familiar" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Does this Sound Familiar?</h3> <p><strong>Techie</strong>: We are drowning in technical debt!</p> <p><strong>Business person</strong>: Oh really! What is it costing us?</p> <p><strong>Techie</strong>: Oh, its not that. What Im saying is the code doesnt use best practices, there are alot of things hard coded and lots of spaghetti code. It makes the code really brittle.</p> <p><strong>Business person</strong>: But can we still deliver what we promised to Big Co Inc?</p> <p><strong>Techie</strong>: Yes, but we will have to do some workarounds. Working on the system is painful and what could have been a one day job will instead take a week. We really need to refactor!</p> <p><strong>Business person</strong>: Ah. That's good news. Our number one priority right now is Big Co Inc.</p> <p><strong>Conclusion</strong>: You dont like your job because it is hard and/or annoying. Will tell your dev manager to ask you to work on the weekend.</p> <h3 id="talking-with-business-leaders"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#talking-with-business-leaders" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Talking with Business Leaders</h3> <p>When we use the term technical debt with non-technical business colleagues, they assume, that technical debt is analogous to financial debt. After a few minutes of discussion they are usually relieved to find that there is no actual money problem. Then after not seeing any tangible sign of a fire in the movie theater, they will then conclude that that we either dont know what we are talking about or we are using the wrong terms or both. Think about their context, how quickly would the CFO get fired if they claimed "we have a lot of debt" but couldnt produce a balance sheet with lenders, amounts, interest rates and terms?</p> <blockquote> <p>how quickly would the CFO get fired if they claimed "we have a lot of debt" but couldnt produce a balance sheet</p> </blockquote> <p></p> <p>In this unprepared conversation we miss a great opportunity to convince that business leader of a course of action we are proposing or to engage in a productive trade-off discussion about risk, investment and priorities. Instead we reinforce the business leaders view that we may know about software but we dont know about business, and that we shouldnt be making decisions about priority.</p> <p></p> <blockquote> <p>Instead we reinforce the business leaders view that we may know about software but we dont know about business</p> </blockquote> <p>In this staged conversation, what we communicated was that technical debt made our job hard and annoying. Notice it did not communicate: an inventory of debt, the ongoing cost to the business and the investment needed to pay it off.</p> <h3 id="how-to-fix-it"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#how-to-fix-it" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>How to Fix It</h3> <p>Companies and business leaders dont care if jobs are hard or annoying or take longer than they "should". The difference between a user story taking a day or 3 days is negligible compared to its business value. Companies and their leaders care about revenue and costs. They care about customers and growth. They care about time to market. If we want to have our non-technical colleagues listen and act, we need to either improve our use of the financial terms they understand or we need to translate our message into business outcomes that they do care about.</p> <p></p> <blockquote> <p>business leaders dont care if jobs are hard or annoying or take longer than they "should" ... we need to translate our message into business outcomes that they do care about</p> </blockquote> <p></p> <p>To capture these opportunities we need to go back to the beginning. The only way to remedy these failures in communication is to refactor our language and use of terms. We need to better define technical debt and the terms we use to describe it. The use of units of dollars is a powerful tool to communicate to those not part of the software design, build, and run value stream. Let's start with how the non-technical listener will understand the terms of debt.</p> <p></p> <blockquote> <p>using a unit of dollars is a powerful tool to communicate to those not part of building software</p> </blockquote> <p></p> <h3 id="what-is-financial-debt"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#what-is-financial-debt" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>What is Financial Debt?</h3> <p><strong>Debt</strong> is a contractual agreement that allows the <strong>borrower</strong> to to shift future <strong>consumption</strong> into the present. This also allows the <strong>lender</strong> to do the reverse, shift present consumption into the future. The amount of consumption that is shifted is the <strong>principal</strong>. The amount that is still due at any point of time is the <strong>balance</strong>. The cost per unit of shifted consumption is the <strong>interest rate</strong>. The distance through time that the consumption is shifted is the <strong>term</strong> of the debt. The frequency and amount that is paid to service the debt is the <strong>payment schedule</strong>. All of these terms should be familiar to most consumers who have a mortgage, credit cards or a car loan.</p> <p>Notice that there is no judgment or statement if debt is good (<strong>productive</strong>) or bad (<strong>unproductive</strong>). If you use debt to purchase a house, is that good or bad? That question can only be answered in the context of the cost of that debt (<strong>interest rate</strong>) and if you are changing your monthly consumption on housing. If your mortgage payment is less than your current rent then it is probably good debt. By borrowing money you have lowered your monthly expenses. This is a productive use of debt.</p> <p>This view of debt is much more inline with how companies reason about their debt. The primary questions are:</p> <ol> <li> <p>What is the cost of the debt?</p> </li> <li> <p>What additional value will the debt buy?</p> </li> <li> <p>What is the expected change to cash flow from this investment?</p> </li> </ol> <p>Borrowing money to build a bigger factory that will enable more efficient production of your products is probably a productive use of debt. Borrowing to fund bonuses for executives is probably unproductive.</p> <h3 id="a-different-conversation"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#a-different-conversation" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>A Different Conversation</h3> <p>If we use these terms to communicate the technical debt we are holding as a team the communication could look like this.</p> <p><strong>Techie</strong>: Oof, we had to give discounts that amounted to 1% of our sales again last month.</p> <p><strong>Business person</strong>: Yeah but what can we do about it?</p> <p><strong>Techie</strong>: Well, our order system is filled with technical debt. We can either keep paying with the discounts for the failed orders, or we can invest in 3-6 weeks of engineering time to half the error rate. This could delay other features.</p> <p><strong>Business person</strong>: If you can half the error rate we can afford to hire more engineers.</p></div></div></div></div> <section id="subscribe-form" class="subscribe-form wf-section"><div class="centered-container w-container"><h2>Subscribe to posts</h2> <p>Enter your email If you would like to get an email the next time we post.<br>We post about ~1-3x per month, and up to once a month about company news.<br></p></div> <div class="container-5 w-container"><div id="embedded-form"></div></div></section> <div class="banner wf-section"><div class="container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-center"><div class="column desk-12"><img src="/images/Rectangle-240-copy.svg" loading="lazy" alt class="absolute-image"> <div class="cta-box"><div class="text-box _600px"><h2>Launch a hello world</h2> <p>Fork and deploy a hello world project onto Cyclic faster than it has taken to read this page. Experience the power.</p> <div class="spacer _24"></div> <a href="https://app.cyclic.sh/api/login?utm_source=www&utm_medium=web&utm_campaign=cta" target="_blank" class="button white w-button">Deploy years I&#39;ve had more passionate discussions about technical debt than any other topic. From all these passionate discussions and online comments I have distilled a taxonomy of the dimensions of debt. What makes a reasoned discussion difficult is that they trade different quantities (mostly unmeasured) of different units across time with different potential probabilities of happening."><meta data-n-head="ssr" data-hid="twitter:description" name="twitter:description" content="As a software professional for almost 20 years I&#39;ve had more passionate discussions about technical debt than any other topic. data-w-id="cb94c0a0-2bab-b0c9-9da8-d93e4ab951f6" xstyle="opacity:0" class="blog-container w-container"><h1>Technical Debt: A Field Guide</h1> <div class="byline"><div class="text-block-6">By:</div> <div><div class="text-block-6">Kam Lasater</div> <a href="https://twitter.com/@seekayel" class="link-2">@seekayel</a></div> <div class="div-block"></div> <div class="text-block-5">Posted: April 19, 2022</div></div> <div class="div-block-2"><a href="#" class="link-block w-inline-block w-clearfix"><div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div> <div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div></a></div> <div class="spacer _32"></div> <div class="rich-text w-richtext"><div class="nuxt-content"><blockquote> <p>I have written previously about how we, as technical professionals, <a href="/posts/we-sound-like-idiots-when-we-talk-about-technical-debt">misuse the term debt and end up sounding like idiots</a> in a business context. This is meant as a companion, to help better communicate, to our non-professional colleagues, what we mean when we say "technical debt".</p> </blockquote> <p></p> <p>As a software professional for almost 20 years (do I get a watch or plaque soon?) I've had more passionate discussions about technical debt than any other topic. It is right up there with the iconic 3rd rail topics: Tabs-v-Spaces, Mac-v-Windows, Java-v-Python and type systems.</p> <p>From all these passionate discussions and online comments I have distilled a taxonomy of the dimensions of debt. All these types of debt at their core describe a trade off in time. Meaning they have a now vs later quality. What makes a reasoned discussion difficult is that they trade different quantities (mostly unmeasured) of different units across time with different potential probabilities of happening.</p> <p>This is what a decision of technical debt could sound like applied to a non-software example. You take your car into the shop since the check engine light came on. The mechanic finds a slow leak in the radiator and offers you the following choices:</p> <ul> <li> <p>do nothing, risking totaling the car if the engine over heats</p> </li> <li> <p>have it resolved in 15 mins for $25, by adding coolant, then $25 every month going forward, otherwise #badthingshappen</p> </li> <li> <p>have it patched by end of day for $150 but then be back in the same position if/when the patch fails</p> </li> <li> <p>have it replaced for $300 but your car will be in the shop for a week for parts to be ordered</p> </li> </ul> <h4 id="so-which-is-the-best-solution-which-do-you-pick"><a href="#so-which-is-the-best-solution-which-do-you-pick" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>So which is the best solution? Which do you pick?</h4> <p>Well, that is impossible to answer. There is no right answer.</p> <p>In this example it depends on:</p> <ul> <li> <p>your expected rate of some future events (how long will patch last? will leak get worse?)</p> </li> <li> <p>your need for the car to be working now (are you leaving on road trip vacation tomorrow?)</p> </li> <li> <p>your expected amount of future use of the car (are you planning to sell the car soon?)</p> </li> <li> <p>your bank account balance? (do you have any money?)</p> </li> <li> <p>your expected future cash flows (do you get paid next friday?)</p> </li> <li> <p>cost to borrow money (how much does your credit card charge?)</p> </li> </ul> <p>It is trivial to construct a scenario where the "obvious" choice would be any one of those options. The dimensions of the choice are:</p> <ul> <li> <p>amount of money now vs later</p> </li> <li> <p>time till the car is working</p> </li> <li> <p>expected usage of the car in the future</p> </li> </ul> <p>Below is my attempt to at least describe and name the dimensions of technical debt akin to naming technical design patterns. If you think I missed a type or mischaracterized a type please tell me on twitter: <a href="https://twitter.com/seekayel" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">@seekayel</a></p> <h1 id="dimensions-of-debt"><a href="#dimensions-of-debt" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Dimensions of Debt</h1> <h2 id="change-time-cost"><a href="#change-time-cost" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Change time cost</h2> <p>Cost:</p> <ul> <li> <p>Any future changes take more time.</p> </li> </ul> <p>How you will hear it described:</p> <ul> <li> <p>If we want to make changes later we will first have to undue this work</p> </li> <li> <p>Next time we will first have to do x, y, z before we can make a change</p> </li> <li> <p>This will make unscheduled Project ABC that we want harder</p> </li> <li> <p>This is brittle and is more likely to break on the next change (increased error rate)</p> </li> <li> <p>On boarding/teaching new people is harder</p> </li> <li> <p>This is a tax on future changes</p> </li> </ul> <p>Financial Similarities:</p> <ul> <li> <p>Bad credit score - all future borrowing will be more expensive</p> </li> <li> <p>Currency wide inflation/devaluation - all future consumption becomes more expensive (assuming you are on a fixed income)</p> </li> </ul> <h2 id="runtime-cost"><a href="#runtime-cost" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Runtime cost</h2> <p>Cost:</p> <ul> <li> <p>Fixed cost in time per unit of time (eg 2hrs per week)</p> </li> <li> <p>Fixed cost in time per unit of system usage (eg 1hr per 1,000 user signups)</p> </li> </ul> <p>How you will hear it described:</p> <ul> <li> <p>We have to spend X hours of support per week</p> </li> <li> <p>20% of our staff hours works on escalations</p> </li> </ul> <p>Financial Translations</p> <ul> <li> <p>Interest only loan - will need to continue to pay until you pay off principle</p> </li> <li> <p>Selling/Buying insurance</p> </li> </ul> <h2 id="opportunity-cost"><a href="#opportunity-cost" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Opportunity Cost</h2> <p>Cost:</p> <ul> <li> <p>Whole sets of features aren't considered or built due to existing code/system/design</p> </li> </ul> <p>How you will hear it described:</p> <ul> <li> <p>We don't build X or Y</p> </li> <li> <p>We don't measure/report on X or Y</p> </li> </ul> <p>Financial Similarities:</p> <ul> <li> <p>Sunk cost fallacy</p> </li> <li> <p>Do you transition the same factory from producing lower value product to higher value product</p> </li> <li> <p>Career transition: forgo income, training/education expense, moving costs for future income</p> </li> </ul> <p>Interpretation:</p> <p>This can be confused with the argument that actions aren't taken because the cost is too high. The focus here should be on the Opportunity that is missed. What could be but isn't, instead of the cost of what is.</p> <h2 id="organizational-risk"><a href="#organizational-risk" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Organizational Risk</h2> <p>Cost:</p> <ul> <li> <p>The organization assumes: financial, reputational, operational or recruiting/retention risk.</p> </li> </ul> <p>How it is described:</p> <ul> <li> <p>If X happens we will have to spend Y days scrambling to fix</p> </li> <li> <p>If it breaks we will have an outage</p> </li> <li> <p>If it breaks we will have a PR disaster/go out of business</p> </li> <li> <p>If it breaks we will be open to legal liability</p> </li> <li> <p>If it breaks we will have a security incident</p> </li> </ul> <p>Financial Similarities:</p> <ul> <li> <p>Selling uncovered puts</p> </li> <li> <p>Selling uncovered calls</p> </li> <li> <p>Uninsured against fire/flood/earthquake</p> </li> <li> <p>Forgivable 0% interest only loan, but potential for demand payment</p> </li> </ul> <p>Interpretation:</p> <p>This can be considered a compound dimension. It could include both the probability that the potential risk occurs along with the probable distribution of potential outcomes. For maximum clarity of communication I would suggest this dimension be discussed as the range of severity of the outcome, if the potential risk comes to pass.</p> <p></p> <h2 id="money-cost"><a href="#money-cost" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Money Cost</h2> <p>Cost:</p> <ul> <li> <p>The organization pays more money aka US Dollars ($) than is strictly necessary.</p> </li> </ul> <p>How it is described:</p> <ul> <li> <p>The servers are too "big"</p> </li> <li> <p>The clusters aren't sized "right"</p> </li> <li> <p>We need to optimize process X for less memory</p> </li> <li> <p>We need to archive some/all of our data/logs</p> </li> <li> <p>We need to turn off things are aren't using</p> </li> </ul> <p>Financial Similarities:</p> <ul> <li> <p>That gym membership that still is charged to your card each month even though you don't go.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Interpretation:</p> <p>This is pretty straight forward, everyone in the organization understands dollars as a unit of cost. Where this is becomes more complicated is in the tradeoffs for any change with: how long it will take, what risk the organization assumes implementing it and the project coordination time to ensure one team's waste isn't another teams KPI.</p> <p></p> <h2 id="postscript"><a href="#postscript" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Postscript</h2> <p>As a business person you will probably be more concerned about Opportunity Cost and Organizational Risk than Runtime Cost or Change Time Cost. What this means for developers is thinking how a particular project you would like prioritized maps to either Opportunity Cost or Organizational Risk is probably a more effective argument than the same for Runtime or Change time costs.</p></div></div></div></div> <section id="subscribe-form" class="subscribe-form wf-section"><div class="centered-container w-container"><h2>Subscribe to posts</h2> <p>Enter your email If you would like to get an email the next time we post.<br>We post about ~1-3x per month, and up to once a month about company news.<br></p></div> <div class="container-5 w-container"><div id="embedded-form"></div></div></section> <div class="banner wf-section"><div class="container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-center"><div class="column desk-12"><img src="/images/Rectangle-240-copy.svg" loading="lazy" alt class="absolute-image"> <div class="cta-box"><div class="text-box _600px"><h2>Launch a hello world</h2> <p>Fork and deploy a hello world project onto Cyclic faster than it has taken to read this page. Experience the power.</p> <div class="spacer _24"></div> <a href="https://app.cyclic.sh/api/login?utm_source=www&utm_medium=web&utm_campaign=cta" target="_blank" class="button white w-button">Deploy on Cyclic </a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div> <div class="footer wf-section"><div class="spacer _64"></div> <div class="footer-container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-top"><div class="column desk-6 tab-12"><a href="/" aria-current="page" data-ix="logo" class="footer-logo w-nav-brand w--current nuxt-link-active"><img src="/images/default-monochrome-white.svg" loading="lazy" alt="cyclic logo" class="image"></a> <p class="paragraph-small no-margin"> 2021-2022 <a href="/" aria-current="page" class="w--current">Cyclic Software</a><br></p> <div class="spacer _64"></div></div> data-server-rendered="true" id="__nuxt"><!----><div id="__layout"><div id="app"><div id="nav-bar-animation" data-collapse="small" data-animation="default" data-duration="400" data-w-id="bd6f9588-23b4-f07d-9f3a-b6bd5f4c319c" data-easing="ease" data-easing2="ease" role="banner" class="nav-bar w-nav"><div class="nav-container w-container"><div class="logo-div"><a href="/" aria-current="page" class="nav-logo w-inline-block w--current nuxt-link-active"><img src="/images/Group-1.png" loading="lazy" width="68" alt="" class="image-2"></a></div> <nav role="navigation" class="nav-content w-nav-menu"><div class="nav-menu"><a href="/pricing" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Pricing</a> <a href="/blog" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Blog</a> <a href="https://docs.cyclic.sh/docs/intro" target="_blank" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Docs</a></div> <div class="nav-cta-button-container"><a href="https://app.cyclic.sh/api/login" data-w-id="bd6f9588-23b4-f07d-9f3a-b6bd5f4c31b7" class="nav-link filled w-nav-link">Sign In</a></div></nav> <div class="menu-button w-nav-button"><img src="/images/White-Menu.svg" loading="lazy" width="24" alt class="menu-icon"></div></div></div> <div><div class="section half-padding wf-section"><div class="container w-container"><div class="blog-image-header"><img src="/content/623b4df73710503348866d01.png" alt class="image-cover"></div></div></div> <div class="section small-padding wf-section"><div data-w-id="cb94c0a0-2bab-b0c9-9da8-d93e4ab951f6" xstyle="opacity:0" class="blog-container w-container"><h1>Its Always Sunny in us-east-1: The gang does business continuity</h1> <div class="byline"><div class="text-block-6">By:</div> <div><div class="text-block-6">Mike Korostelev</div> <a href="https://twitter.com/@korostelevm" class="link-2">@korostelevm</a></div> <div class="div-block"></div> <div class="text-block-5">Posted: April 19, 2022</div></div> <div class="div-block-2"><a href="#" class="link-block w-inline-block w-clearfix"><div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div> <div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div></a></div> <div class="spacer _32"></div> <div class="rich-text w-richtext"><div class="nuxt-content"><p><em>TLDR: The gang experiences an AWS outage; customers report SHOWSTOPPERs; the gang triages the issues and attempts to implement an elaborate disaster recovery plan</em></p> <p>It is 11:03 AM on a Thursday, US-EAST-1, Pennsylvania. You've been triple booked just right and everyone at each call thinks you're at the other call. In this rare moment of freedom, you are adding custom emojis to slack.</p> <p>A message from a developer:</p> <p><img alt="" src="/content/623b2bac320ad6b1f2c29c14_nb5Pt8iNWIeakqh64ZRzCdyvwQJoh5dqa3DLMw3VuRharHKff1CBXKBUKWtXIIxBIXOcFpaMW6VXC-vq9STLnr4_H1O16CU8P2N6jGPXMaiaa7njhzSLGvsqih8h-zkX0OIMDeLs.png"></p> <ul> <li>"dude you free? we're having failures in prod."</li> </ul> <p>This is unfortunate, it is your week on support rotation so the other calls cant get you out of this one.</p> <h2 id="the-triage-process"><a href="#the-triage-process" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>The triage process</h2> <p>You've crafted your triage process over many incidents and honed cutting diagnostic inquisitions. The goal here is efficiency and the mitigation of risk to lunchtime and as always, the secondary objective to expose the truth about how the PR comment you left was ignored and best practices spitefully neglected.</p> <p><strong>1. Estimate priority</strong>: Did a customer report it? Did we find it ourselves?</p> <ul> <li>"No we saw alarms but no one knows yet, support team is doing these manually"</li> </ul> <p><strong>2. Assess impact</strong>: How many have failed?</p> <ul> <li>"A few, we've seen it earlier this morning, we think it might be AWS or they might be one-offs"</li> </ul> <p><strong>3. Establish precise language:</strong> A few is not a number, earlier is not a timestamp. Did you check the AWS status page?</p> <ul> <li>"Just messaged support team. Checking AWS status now..."</li> <li>"AWS status is "</li> </ul> <p><strong>4. Identify patterns</strong>: Are they all failing the same way? What is the error signature?</p> <ul> <li>"Its <em>random</em>, some of them timed out after <strong><em>random</em></strong> time, some have errors <strong>randomly</strong>."</li> </ul> <p><strong>5. Analyze chain of events</strong>: What did we change last?</p> <ul> <li>"Nothing, the last deployment was two weeks ago"</li> </ul> <p>The nuances in this last question is that a lot happens outside of the standard change management process. Some of these off-the-record/alternative-record things covered in triage include:</p> <ul> <li>Configuration changes made to toggle features</li> <li>New users introduced never before seen behaviors</li> <li>Off-cycle hot-fixes deployed from feature branches</li> </ul> <p>These three, plus the normal sprint work is at best recorded into only four different systems of record. Each of the systems is almost certainly the best tool for its job and each probably even has excellent integration capabilities. Unfortunately, the four are integrated manually in excel by four different people producing out-of-sync csv exports.</p> <p><strong>6. Initiate holy crusade</strong>: Some of the worst atrocities committed against software get to production under the guise of hot-fixes. The perpetrators must be identified.</p> <ul> <li>"We should call in _______, I think they were on the last incident call"</li> </ul> <p></p> <p>This continues as more participants join the call - until - even though AWS status page is still showing , someone announces:</p> <h3 id="some-people-on-twitter-are-saying-aws-is-having-an-outage-in-us-east-1"><a href="#some-people-on-twitter-are-saying-aws-is-having-an-outage-in-us-east-1" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong>"Some people on twitter are saying AWS is having an outage in us-east-1"</strong></h3> <p><em>If you get nothing else out of this article - please walk away with this: If</em> <em>you are having doubts about the status of AWS, check twitter.</em></p> <p><strong>This is good news.</strong></p> <p>While numerous system failure notifications are signaling that <strong>shit is hitting the fan</strong>, the mood on the call improves briefly as all are absolved of any potential guilt, its no ones fault.</p> <h1 id="disaster-"><a href="#disaster-" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong>Disaster</strong> </h1> <p>This calm is short lived, the customers have been notified. They've escalated pissed-ness from <code>CRITICAL</code> to <code>SHOWSTOPPER</code> (from the resting baseline of <code>URGENT</code>). They are asking for an ETA on the resolution and hourly updates on the status.</p> <p>Large organizations have <em>Recovery Time Objective (RTO)</em> and <em>Recovery Point Objective (RPO)</em> standards for disaster/outage scenarios. RTO/RPO can be internal standards or sometimes compliance requirements. What RPO/RTO actually means is best illustrated with an example:</p> <p><em>If you're playing a video game - a crash is a disaster. The time it takes to boot the game back up is the recovery time. When the game starts back up, you've lost some progress time and have to start from an earlier autosave - thats the recovery point.</em></p> <p>The goal is to have systems in place to maintain business continuity by reducing data loss and minimizing downtime for end users. This is done by deploying redundant infrastructure and data backups in alternate locations since physical infrastructure is geographically vulnerable.</p> <h1 id="recovery-strategy"><a href="#recovery-strategy" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Recovery Strategy</h1> <p>The org's AWS technical account manager tries to reassure everyone by confirming that issue is <strong>only regional</strong>. Having seen an amazing disaster recovery demo from the tech team six months ago, an executive on the call, feeling like they're about to save the day asks:</p> <ul> <li>`"We built DR capability. Why can't we recover to east-2?"</li> </ul> <p>This is where we discover that DR capability is different from a DR demo proving that failover is possible. Software changes over time. If there is an expectation that the application has recovery capability, each change must be made with the consideration for how it will behave in failure scenarios. To be clear - not try/except wrapping some new code for some feature - but how will the system with this new code and feature behave when infrastructure around it starts to break. <strong>Adopting DR is a culture change that goes beyond the developer.</strong> Maintaining availability requires continuous overhead in time and effort on development, management and architecture.</p> <p>The answer is to this question is as usual -</p> <ul> <li>"We could try it but we're not sure what would happen, we have to ask the devops lead, but they're out today."</li> </ul> <p>The contributing factors to this lack of confidence come from those same nuances of the <code>What did we change last?</code> question.</p> <p>When the devops lead is finally located. They remember that something has changed since the DR demo. The recovery process has changed and someone has to write an additional script. They explain the functionality briefly but unfortunately they can't do it. They have "a hard stop" and have "to drop" to watch their pets and children on their day off. They will then hand-off to you.</p> <p>35 highly paid managers on the call that are normally skeptical of pair programming - become an engaged operating theater audience to a couple of developers <a href="https://www.cyclic.sh/posts/write-shitty-code" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">hacking together a script</a> that will never make it to version control.</p> <p>When the script is finally written, <strong>a decision must be made.</strong></p> <h1 id="ok-should-we-run-it"><a href="#ok-should-we-run-it" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>"Ok should we run it?"</h1> <p>The story has had a number of twists so far. It was determined that the original recovery plan is out of date and had to be duct taped back together. The plan's original creators have given their warnings and <strong>someone new must own the success or failure of the recovery</strong>. The decision should be made with caution of course, and so, the risks need to be discussed.</p> <p>QA will list the environments they would like the script to be tested in, the business execs will bring up the need to work together on this with other organizational units. A few more people will join the call for a final per-hour burn rate approaching a developers monthly salary.</p> <p><strong>AWS will inevitably fix us-east-1, and very probably before the discussion concludes.</strong> Someone will interrupt to announce:</p> <ul> <li>"We're seeing less failures, looks like we're good!"</li> </ul> <p>Everyone congratulates everyone on their hard work. The tech team sees a bright and hopeful future. They vow to bring this up in the post-mortem as an indisputable argument to <a href="https://www.cyclic.sh/posts/we-sound-like-idiots-when-we-talk-about-technical-debt" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">convince product to finally pay down the tech debt</a>.</p> <p></p> <h1 id="-educational-content"><a href="#%EF%B8%8F-educational-content" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a> <strong>Educational content</strong></h1> <p>There are multiple <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/architecture/disaster-recovery-dr-architecture-on-aws-part-i-strategies-for-recovery-in-the-cloud/" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">very well documented strategies</a> and architecture patterns to achieving recovery objectives. While there is a number of these, they can be reduced to just two:</p> <ul> <li>Active-Active - multiple independent, regionally redundant and interoperable systems functioning concurrently and as mutual back-ups without needing to be manually switched over</li> <li>Not Active-Active - dusty, manually run Rube Goldberg machines designed for impressive demos and can only be operated by one dude who happens to be on vacation</li> </ul> <p><img alt="" src="/content/623b37698dc82a7ba4eda92f_BG_oAOIfVIFsvST2nqtZfBEzcpuAP6QipgKosUKp9EBYAQ_wUUDSvoXNoe1l7XW_4KIC_TZ9BTjVxmHgimWyA5p9Vp4_QGzRjIXuXmA3vId-F5K2OQlyPpEkdkS9b9ZFmzfEcOak.png"></p> <p>please share all of your great successes with manually orchestrating active-passive/pilot light recoveries in the comments</p> <p></p> <p>There is nothing fundamentally wrong about the passive approaches to recovery. The real problem is that unless the organization has capacity to continuously pay the overhead of maintaining and practicing recovery strategies, the recovery plan will always be out of date like in the story above. In active-active configuration, application have to naturally become regionally agnostic and shifting from one region to another naturally has to be automatic.</p> <p>It is true that for many systems, especially those built on always-on infrastructure that have a per-hour cost, active-active is really expensive. For every compute instance you have serving traffic, you need to have another that is also turned on in a different region.</p> <p>On-demand pricing is common for most products calling themselves serverless. With that, redundancy doesn't have to cost double and with much of serverless being heavily config driven the complexity is also reduced.</p> <p></p> <p><strong>We will be posting a series on building global applications with serverless. Check out the first part in the series >></strong> <a href="https://www.cyclic.sh/posts/considerations-for-serverless-active-active-routing" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Routing and Health Checks</a></p> <p></p> <p></p></div></div></div></div> <section id="subscribe-form" class="subscribe-form wf-section"><div class="centered-container w-container"><h2>Subscribe to posts</h2> <p>Enter your email If you would like to get an email the next time we post.<br>We post about ~1-3x per month, and up to once a month about company news.<br></p></div> <div class="container-5 w-container"><div id="embedded-form"></div></div></section> <div class="banner wf-section"><div class="container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-center"><div class="column desk-12"><img src="/images/Rectangle-240-copy.svg" loading="lazy" alt class="absolute-image"> <div class="cta-box"><div class="text-box _600px"><h2>Launch a hello world</h2> <p>Fork and deploy a hello world project onto Cyclic faster than it has taken to read this page. Experience the power.</p> <div class="spacer _24"></div> <a href="https://app.cyclic.sh/api/login?utm_source=www&utm_medium=web&utm_campaign=cta" target="_blank" class="button white w-button">Deploy on Cyclic </a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div> <div class="footer wf-section"><div class="spacer _64"></div> <div class="footer-container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-top"><div class="column desk-6 tab-12"><a href="/" aria-current="page" data-ix="logo" class="footer-logo w-nav-brand w--current nuxt-link-active"><img src="/images/default-monochrome-white.svg" loading="lazy" alt="cyclic logo" class="image"></a> <p class="paragraph-small no-margin"> 2021-2022 <a href="/" aria-current="page" class="w--current">Cyclic Software</a><br></p> <div class="spacer _64"></div></div> <div class="column desk-2 tab-4 mob-6"></div> <div class="column desk-2 tab-4 mob-6"><div class="footer-links-container"><h5 class="footer-header">Social</h5> <a item.title: AWS S3: Why sometimes you should press the $100k button
