data-server-rendered="true" id="__nuxt"><!----><div id="__layout"><div id="app"><div id="nav-bar-animation" data-collapse="small" data-animation="default" data-duration="400" data-w-id="bd6f9588-23b4-f07d-9f3a-b6bd5f4c319c" data-easing="ease" data-easing2="ease" role="banner" class="nav-bar w-nav"><div class="nav-container w-container"><div class="logo-div"><a href="/" class="nav-content w-nav-menu"><div class="nav-menu"><a href="/pricing" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Pricing</a> <a href="/blog" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Blog</a> <a href="https://docs.cyclic.sh/docs/intro" target="_blank" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Docs</a></div> <div class="nav-cta-button-container"><a href="https://app.cyclic.sh/api/login" data-w-id="bd6f9588-23b4-f07d-9f3a-b6bd5f4c31b7" class="nav-link filled w-nav-link">Sign In</a></div></nav> <div class="menu-button w-nav-button"><img src="/images/White-Menu.svg" loading="lazy" width="24" alt class="menu-icon"></div></div></div> <div><div class="section half-padding wf-section"><div class="container w-container"><div class="blog-image-header"><img src="/content/620c1848220192d9c4b7ca2d.png" alt class="image-cover"></div></div></div> <div class="section small-padding wf-section"><div data-w-id="cb94c0a0-2bab-b0c9-9da8-d93e4ab951f6" xstyle="opacity:0" class="blog-container w-container"><h1>AWS S3: Why sometimes you should press the $100k button</h1> <div class="byline"><div class="text-block-6">By:</div> <div><div class="text-block-6">Mike Korostelev</div> <a href="https://twitter.com/@korostelevm" class="link-2">@korostelevm</a></div> <div class="div-block"></div> <div class="text-block-5">Posted: February 17, 2022</div></div> <div class="div-block-2"><a href="#" class="link-block w-inline-block w-clearfix"><div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div> <div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div></a></div> <div class="spacer _32"></div> <div class="rich-text w-richtext"><div class="nuxt-content"><p><em>(a short story inspired by true events)</em></p> <blockquote> <p>TLDR: Mere mortals implement best practices for S3 read and write performance, create a million billion s3 objects with their high performance system, try to clean up the really really expensive mess and find themselves in a <em>dimension as vast as space and as timeless as infinity.</em></p> </blockquote> <p></p> <p>In the days before BigQuery and S3's unlimited object storage, data was finite and predictable. The constraint drove engineers and architects to decide what they would and would not store at design time. Rigid data models and schemas were put in place. The data at rest was kept safe from developers behind dedicated teams with God mode SQL permissions.</p> <p></p> <h3 id="today-managed-services-have-delivered-on-their-great-promise-"><a href="#today-managed-services-have-delivered-on-their-great-promise-" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Today managed services have delivered on their <strong><em>great promise</em></strong> .</h3> <p>Today managed services have delivered on their great promise. You can now grow your MVP to enterprise scale and all the things are taken care of for you. </p> <p>Now, AWS Kinesis can dump <a href="https://docs.aws.amazon.com/firehose/latest/dev/limits.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">half a million</a> (soft limit) records per second into an S3 bucket. If you don't know where to find half a million of records per second, a handy menu of <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/eventbridge/integrations/" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">channel partners</a> is available on the console. They are ready to pipe it to you with only a few clicks_. (But dont worry, versioning is probably enabled on your bucket and some runaway recursive ghost code is endlessly touching some config file.)_</p> <p>The NDJSON is flowing, data scientists are on-boarded and life is really great for a while, until one day; at one of the many many status meetings the leadership points out that your group has <strong>burned through the cloud budget for the year, and it is only May</strong>. In cost explorer, the trickle from multiple firehoses has accumulated into an S3 storage bill of almost $100k/month.</p> <blockquote> <p>... the trickle from multiple firehoses has accumulated into an <strong>S3 storage bill of almost $100k/month</strong>.</p> </blockquote> <p>This <strong>sounds like a disaster</strong>, but it's not the end of the world, right? At least the problem is measurable. And after all, you can just delete a bunch of objects and move a bunch of the remaining junk to AWS Glacier (or whatever they just changed the name to).<strong></strong></p> <h3 id="or-can-you"><a href="#or-can-you" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong>Or can you?</strong></h3> <h5 id="-documentation-references-ahead-"><a href="#%EF%B8%8F-documentation-references-ahead-%EF%B8%8F" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong></strong> Documentation References Ahead </h5> <p>S3 objects are named by their Bucket and Prefix -For the S3 objects :</p> <div class="nuxt-content-highlight"><pre class="language-text line-numbers"><code>s3://my-bucket-us-east-2/app/events/login-123123.json s3://my-bucket-us-east-2/app/events/logout-436564.json </code></pre></div> <p>The json files named <code>login-123123.json</code> and <code>logout-436564.json</code> are not actually in a folder called events nested in another called app.</p> <p>The files are stored on a physical drive somewhere and indexed someplace else by the entire string <code>app/events/</code> - called the prefix. The <code>/</code> character is really just a rendered delimiter. You can actually specify <a href="https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/using-prefixes.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">whatever you want</a> to be the delimiter for list/scan apis.</p> <p>Anyway, under the hood, these prefixes are used to shard and partition data in S3 buckets across whatever wires and metal boxes in physical data centers. Since any character can be a delimiter, this actually happens over time as AWSdiscovers the access patterns for the data. This is important because whileAWSwill adapt to any pattern - the prefix design drives access patterns for human developers and impacts performance in large scale high volume read and write applications.</p> <p>The limits on reads and writes are:</p> <ul> <li>3,500 PUT/COPY/POST/DELETE requests per second per prefix</li> <li>5,500 GET/HEAD requests per second per prefix</li> </ul> <p>This means you can make up to 3500 write / 5500 read requests per second to add or look at <code>app/events/</code> files. Higher than that, and you may experience <code>503</code> or <code>429</code> errors, especially with burst traffic.</p> <p>When faced with the challenge of producing or accessing big data with practical performance - <a href="https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/optimizing-performance.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Best practices</a>, enterprise support, and your technical account manager (TAM) will recommend that you:</p> <blockquote> <p>... use an object key naming pattern that distributes your objects across multiple prefixes.</p> </blockquote> <h3 id="tech-debt"><a href="#tech-debt" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Tech debt</h3> <p>These best practices are usually overlooked in early MVPs and objects are likely stored with the familiar <code>folder/file</code> pattern. It doesn't take long for the issue to expose itself. The first performance issues are usually experienced on read when someone first tries large scale queries with tools like AWS Athena and competes with the customer-facing processes for S3 reads.</p> <p>This is chalked up as a <a href="https://www.cyclic.sh/posts/we-sound-like-idiots-when-we-talk-about-technical-debt" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">repaying tech-debt</a> and work is done to adapt the existing patterns to best practices. Processes that used to produce <code>app/events/login-123123.json</code> are refactored to write <code>app/events/dt=yyyy-mm-dd/login-123123.json</code> instead. (Actually something like app/events/dt=yyyy-mm-dd/asdfasdfasdf.gz , building crawler schema to make parquet out of messy, dynamic json files is hard and you think you're smart and just enable gzip compression in firehose.)</p> <p><strong>Cool.</strong> You configure the partition key <code>dt=yyyy-mm-dd</code> in the data catalog, write some documentation about how everyone should use date ranges to make queries efficient. All is well and the data science team can again do linear regressions aka "Machine Learning" to find out which events make the most money or, you know "drive business kpis".</p> <h3 id="back-to-our-original-problem"><a href="#back-to-our-original-problem" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Back to our original problem</h3> <p>Some time has passed and <strong>you now have a shitload of data in S3</strong>. Someone has noticed how much it costs and <strong>now you have to clean it up</strong>.</p> <p>Hopefully, AWS is holding your hand on this one - you're a really great customer obviously.They will tell you, the two options you have to clean stuff up are:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Delete objects one by one</strong> manually by using the list and delete APIs <em>(yeah, sounds dumb)</em></li> <li><strong>Set up lifecycle policies</strong> at the bucket level to expire objects based on prefix rules <em>(this sounds promising!!)</em></li> </ul> <p>Lifecycle policies are pretty great.</p> <p>They work by first specifying a filter like:</p> <ul> <li>Apply by tag <em>(That would be sweet.. but no one tagged any of the objects that are already in there)</em></li> <li>Apply by a size threshold <em>(There is no meaningful size difference between stuff you might want or not want)</em></li> <li>Apply by prefix <em>(Yeeeah, that's the one)</em></li> </ul> <p>Then specifying a rule like:</p> <ul> <li>Expire after some time has passed</li> <li>Move to a different storage class</li> <li>Delete older versions of objects</li> </ul> <h3 id="stop-the-bleeding"><a href="#stop-the-bleeding" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Stop the bleeding</h3> <p>Without much research, the prefix filter thing looks really good. Naturally, as it is with filters, everyone would need to decide what they want to keep and not keep. That sounds like a mess of calls and meetings. On that dilemma, the (actually good) advice from your partners at AWS</p> <blockquote> <p>"Your costs are accumulating, we can help you move the really old stuff to Glacier to stop the bleeding."<br> - Some AWSbro</p> </blockquote> <p>There are obvious tradeoffs with Glacier. But since large scale reads, especially ones on old data are not often done, after some short all-hands discussions everyone agrees.</p> <h3 id="the-100-thousand-dollar-button"><a href="#the-100-thousand-dollar-button" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>The 100 thousand dollar button</h3> <p>You go back and press the button in the console. A message comes up asking you to confirm that you are aware that:</p> <p><img alt="" src="/content/620d170b68d74639eb4fe9f1.png"></p> <p>But isn't there like a million billion objects?? How about a different storage class? <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/s3/pricing/" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Requests & data retrievals</a> > Lifecycle Transition requests into (per 1,000 requests). Even though the s3 console does not produce the ominous warning when selecting other storage classes, <a href="https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/lifecycle-transition-general-considerations.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">transitional request charges apply</a>. <strong>Fuuuuuuuuu<br> </strong><br> Doing metrics inventory with some help from AWS on your billions of json files and a little math - it is determined that <strong>pressing this button will incur a one time cost of around $100,000</strong>.</p> <p>Very few people (all non-technical) in the organization have the ability to authorize this. No one (or at least not the mere mortals) wants to be the one to give those people this news. There goes Plan A. On to plan B: Figure out what can be deleted.</p> <p>Before this gets escalated, you rush to set up meetings with stakeholders. Data science says keep all the logins but dont care about logouts. The application team needs both but only for a week or so. Compliance says some things can be archived but archives must be kept for a year. Complicated, but for now there is something to say at the status meetings - "We're working on it."</p> <blockquote> <p>"We're working on it."</p> <p>- everyone in every status meeting ever</p> </blockquote> <h3 id="lifecycle-policies-are-not-magic"><a href="#lifecycle-policies-are-not-magic" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Lifecycle policies are not magic</h3> <p>Fast forward through three months of weekly status meetings, working with different teams to document data retention requirements. Yes, the bills were paid, more stuff has been stored and costs have risen, but - <strong>there is finally a list!</strong></p> <p>You will archive the logouts after 30 days and delete after a year for compliance, logins will be kept for 6 months for the data science team, archived... etc. etc.</p> <p></p> <p><strong>Now here is the twist.</strong> Somehow over many meetings, AWS support calls, etc - the story of how prefix filters work has morphed into how everyone wanted it to work. Checking back in with support - you find out that <code>app/events/\*/login-\*.json</code> and <code>app/events/\*/logout-\*.json</code> is not actually going to magically scan wildcard patterns. It's the flip side of the partitioning coin. <strong>The thing that makes reads and writes so performant makes it impossible to implement wildcards in lifecycle policies.</strong></p> <p>How did everyone come to the misunderstanding? (well other than by not reading the docs) Could it be coming across <a href="https://docs.aws.amazon.com/mediastore/latest/ug/policies-object-lifecycle-components.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">similar language in docs for a different AWSservice</a> that does have wildcards? Skimming over <a href="http://www.deplication.net/2019/02/aws-tip-wildcard-characters-in-s3.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">blog posts</a> on the subject? The <a href="https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/intro-lifecycle-rules.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">S3 docs</a> not telling you explicitly that you can't do that? <em>(Comments welcome)</em></p> <h3 id="the-truth"><a href="#the-truth" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>The Truth</h3> <p>Faced with this truth, the heroes realize that a lot of time has been put into crafting those rules, lists were made, arguments were had. There is no going back to Plan A now. A few sprints later - developer gets a user story: <strong>Use big-ass SageMaker to crawl s3 and clean up</strong> <em>(3 points.</em></p> <p>Whether or not the org is still paying that bill has been lost to history but legend says that user story got de-prioritized.</p></div></div></div></div> <section id="subscribe-form" class="subscribe-form wf-section"><div class="centered-container w-container"><h2>Subscribe to posts</h2> <p>Enter your email If you would like to get an email the next time we post.<br>We post about ~1-3x per month, and up to once a month about company news.<br></p></div> <div class="container-5 w-container"><div id="embedded-form"></div></div></section> <div class="banner wf-section"><div class="container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-center"><div class="column desk-12"><img src="/images/Rectangle-240-copy.svg" loading="lazy" alt class="absolute-image"> <div class="cta-box"><div class="text-box _600px"><h2>Launch a hello world</h2> <p>Fork and deploy a hello world project onto Cyclic faster than it has taken to read this page. Experience the power.</p> <div class="spacer _24"></div> <a href="https://app.cyclic.sh/api/login?utm_source=www&utm_medium=web&utm_campaign=cta" target="_blank" class="button white w-button">Deploy on Cyclic </a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div> <div class="footer wf-section"><div class="spacer _64"></div> <div class="footer-container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-top"><div class="column desk-6 tab-12"><a href="/" aria-current="page" data-ix="logo" class="footer-logo w-nav-brand w--current nuxt-link-active"><img src="/images/default-monochrome-white.svg" loading="lazy" alt="cyclic logo" class="image"></a> <p class="paragraph-small no-margin"> 2021-2022 <a href="/" aria-current="page" class="w--current">Cyclic Software</a><br></p> <div class="spacer _64"></div></div> data-server-rendered="true" id="__nuxt"><!----><div id="__layout"><div id="app"><div id="nav-bar-animation" data-collapse="small" data-animation="default" data-duration="400" data-w-id="bd6f9588-23b4-f07d-9f3a-b6bd5f4c319c" data-easing="ease" data-easing2="ease" role="banner" class="nav-bar w-nav"><div class="nav-container w-container"><div class="logo-div"><a href="/" aria-current="page" class="nav-logo w-inline-block w--current nuxt-link-active"><img src="/images/Group-1.png" loading="lazy" width="68" alt="" class="image-2"></a></div> <nav role="navigation" class="nav-content w-nav-menu"><div class="nav-menu"><a href="/pricing" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Pricing</a> <a href="/blog" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Blog</a> <a href="https://docs.cyclic.sh/docs/intro" target="_blank" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Docs</a></div> <div class="nav-cta-button-container"><a href="https://app.cyclic.sh/api/login" data-w-id="bd6f9588-23b4-f07d-9f3a-b6bd5f4c31b7" class="nav-link filled w-nav-link">Sign In</a></div></nav> <div class="menu-button w-nav-button"><img src="/images/White-Menu.svg" loading="lazy" width="24" alt class="menu-icon"></div></div></div> <div><div class="section half-padding wf-section"><div class="container w-container"><div class="blog-image-header"><img src="/content/62a102a37f0978da6079c6f4_StockSnap_IQ2LORUXQB.jpg" alt class="image-cover"></div></div></div> <div class="section small-padding wf-section"><div data-w-id="cb94c0a0-2bab-b0c9-9da8-d93e4ab951f6" xstyle="opacity:0" class="blog-container w-container"><h1>How to Debug</h1> <div class="byline"><div class="text-block-6">By:</div> <div><div class="text-block-6">Kam Lasater</div> <a href="https://twitter.com/@seekayel" class="link-2">@seekayel</a></div> <div class="div-block"></div> <div class="text-block-5">Posted: June 13, 2022</div></div> <div class="div-block-2"><a href="#" class="link-block w-inline-block w-clearfix"><div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div> <div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div></a></div> <div class="spacer _32"></div> <div class="rich-text w-richtext"><div class="nuxt-content"><p>We all hit bugs that feel impossible to diagnose. The hardest ones to debug are intermittent or inconsistent. How do I fix what works sometimes? If a line of code always breaks then the fix is direct. The system is linear. The action leads to a failure.</p> <p></p> <p>How do I debug a bug that is intermittent? How do I debug something that works sometimes?</p> <p></p> <p>Here are some reminders to myself next time I encounter a baffling debugging session.</p> <p></p> <h2 id="choose-learning"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#choose-learning" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Choose Learning</h2> <p></p> <p>My greatest learnings come from debugging. This bug is an opportunity for me to learn more about this system. If I already knew what was causing the problem then I wouldn't have a bug. The fact that I have a bug that isnt obvious to me on how to fix, by definition means I have a chance to learn.</p> <p></p> <p>The system is giving me the gift of the chance to learn.</p> <p></p> <p>Choose to take the opportunity to learn.</p> <p></p> <h2 id="chase-the-error"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#chase-the-error" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Chase the Error</h2> <p></p> <p>Answer the question: "how do I make this fail every single time?"</p> <p></p> <p>Instead of continuing to make the system work. Instead make the system fail. Go straight at the error. Maximize it. Increase the error rate. Trigger the error repeatedly.</p> <p></p> <p>Focus on driving the error rate to 100%. Only then can I be sure any success is from my action and not inconsistency.</p> <p></p> <p>Make predictions to test my understanding: "The system will fail, now (pushes button)"</p> <p></p> <h2 id="simplify"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#simplify" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Simplify</h2> <p></p> <p>Once I can create the error on demand, I isolate. I begin simplifying the steps to trigger. Remove steps or hard code responses. Trim excess complexity not needed to cause error.</p> <p></p> <p>If it takes 6 steps to reproduce, try turning each one off in order.</p> <p></p> <p>Find the minimum degrees of freedom to still reproduce the error.</p> <p></p> <h2 id="assess-the-inverse"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#assess-the-inverse" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Assess the Inverse</h2> <p></p> <p>Reminder: the error is not caused by something I understand. Look explicitly for areas where I assume the system is working.</p> <p></p> <p>What are the parts of the system that I am sure are working? What if they werent working as I expected? Verify the components are actually working as I expect.</p> <p></p> <p>Reminder: Its not what we dont know that gets us into trouble, it is what we know for sure that isn't true</p> <p></p> <h2 id="devise-a-conclusive-measure"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#devise-a-conclusive-measure" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Devise a Conclusive Measure</h2> <p></p> <p>Brainstorm what report, measure, logging or data would definitely tell me what is causing the error. Maybe this won't tell me "why" the error is happening, but point me closer to "where" the error is being caused.</p> <p></p> <p>Question: What piece of information would conclusively tell me what the problem was?</p> <p></p> <h2 id="take-a-break"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#take-a-break" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Take a Break</h2> <p></p> <p>I might be making things worse. If I dont know what causes the error I dont know if Im making it worse. If the situation allows for it, take a break.</p> <p></p> <p>Get some air. Go for a walk. Breath.</p> <p></p> <p>A clear relaxed mind is open for new ideas.</p> <p></p> <p>Sleep on it. Pick it up tomorrow.</p> <p></p> <h2 id="explain-how-to-reproduce"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#explain-how-to-reproduce" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Explain How to Reproduce</h2> <p></p> <p>Say it out loud.</p> <p>Talk to myself.</p> <p>Explain the steps to reproduce.</p> <p>Start at the beginning.</p> <p>Back up three steps and explain again.</p> <p>Slower this time.</p> <p></p> <h2 id="summary"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#summary" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Summary</h2> <p></p> <p>Hopefully this helps you debug an issue you are struggling with. If you have other techniques or improvements to these let me know: twitter.com/seekayel</p> <p></p> <p>For those who jump to the end, here is the tldr:</p> <p></p> <ol> <li>Choose Learning</li> <li>Chase the Error</li> <li>Simplify</li> <li>Assess the Inverse</li> <li>Devise a Conclusive Measure</li> <li>Take a Break</li> <li>Explain How to Reproduce</li> </ol> <p></p></div></div></div></div> <section id="subscribe-form" class="subscribe-form wf-section"><div class="centered-container w-container"><h2>Subscribe to posts</h2> <p>Enter your email If you would like to get an email the next time we post.<br>We post about ~1-3x per month, and up to once a month about company news.<br></p></div> <div class="container-5 w-container"><div id="embedded-form"></div></div></section> <div class="banner wf-section"><div class="container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-center"><div class="column desk-12"><img src="/images/Rectangle-240-copy.svg" loading="lazy" alt class="absolute-image"> <div class="cta-box"><div class="text-box _600px"><h2>Launch a hello world</h2> <p>Fork and deploy a hello world project onto Cyclic faster than it has taken to read this page. Experience the power.</p> <div class="spacer _24"></div> <a href="https://app.cyclic.sh/api/login?utm_source=www&utm_medium=web&utm_campaign=cta" target="_blank" class="button white w-button">Deploy on Cyclic </a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div> <div class="footer wf-section"><div class="spacer _64"></div> <div class="footer-container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-top"><div class="column desk-6 tab-12"><a href="/" aria-current="page" data-ix="logo" class="footer-logo w-nav-brand w--current nuxt-link-active"><img src="/images/default-monochrome-white.svg" loading="lazy" alt="cyclic logo" class="image"></a> <p class="paragraph-small no-margin"> 2021-2022 <a href="/" aria-current="page" class="w--current">Cyclic Software</a><br></p> <div class="spacer _64"></div></div> <div class="column desk-2 tab-4 mob-6"></div> <div class="column desk-2 tab-4 mob-6"><div class="footer-links-container"><h5 class="footer-header">Social</h5> <a href="https://github.com/cyclic-software" target="_blank" class="footer-link">Github</a> <a href="https://discord.cyclic.sh" target="_blank" class="footer-link">Discord </a> <a href="https://twitter.com/cyclicsoftware" target="_blank" class="footer-link">Twitter</a></div></div> <div class="column desk-2 tab-4 mob-6"><div class="footer-links-container"><h5 class="footer-header">Company</h5> <a href="/pricing" class="footer-link">Pricing</a> <a href="/blog" class="footer-link">Blog</a> <a href="https://docs.cyclic.sh/docs/intro" target="_blank" data-w-id="bd6f9588-23b4-f07d-9f3a-b6bd5f4c319c" data-easing="ease" data-easing2="ease" role="banner" class="nav-bar w-nav"><div class="nav-container w-container"><div class="logo-div"><a href="/" aria-current="page" class="nav-logo w-inline-block w--current nuxt-link-active"><img src="/images/Group-1.png" loading="lazy" width="68" alt="" class="image-2"></a></div> <nav role="navigation" class="nav-content w-nav-menu"><div class="nav-menu"><a href="/pricing" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Pricing</a> <a href="/blog" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Blog</a> <a href="https://docs.cyclic.sh/docs/intro" target="_blank" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Docs</a></div> <div class="nav-cta-button-container"><a href="https://app.cyclic.sh/api/login" data-w-id="bd6f9588-23b4-f07d-9f3a-b6bd5f4c31b7" class="nav-link filled w-nav-link">Sign In</a></div></nav> <div class="menu-button w-nav-button"><img src="/images/White-Menu.svg" loading="lazy" width="24" alt class="menu-icon"></div></div></div> <div><div class="section half-padding wf-section"><div class="container w-container"><div class="blog-image-header"><img src="/content/62a74a26dc596b3c205de748_ryan-moreno-Lurw1nCIkLc-unsplash.jpg" alt class="image-cover"></div></div></div> <div class="section small-padding wf-section"><div data-w-id="cb94c0a0-2bab-b0c9-9da8-d93e4ab951f6" xstyle="opacity:0" class="blog-container w-container"><h1>6 Command line Tools All Experts Know</h1> <div class="byline"><div class="text-block-6">By:</div> <div><div class="text-block-6">Kam Lasater</div> <a href="https://twitter.com/@seekayel" class="link-2">@seekayel</a></div> <div class="div-block"></div> <div class="text-block-5">Posted: June 13, 2022</div></div> <div class="div-block-2"><a href="#" class="link-block w-inline-block w-clearfix"><div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div> <div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div></a></div> <div class="spacer _32"></div> <div class="rich-text w-richtext"><div class="nuxt-content"><p>I work on Mac OSX and Linux command line environments. My tool kit is shaped by the needs I have. This is my tool box of tools that work with almost any command and help me go from just using the command line to being an expert.</p> <p>Wow, your friends and colleagues. These tools make every other command at the command line more powerful.</p> <h2 id="-aka-pipe"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#-aka-pipe" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong>| (aka pipe)</strong></h2> <p>Pipe is awesome. It lets me connect the output of one command and "pipe" it into the input of another command. This is the universal glue that instantly lets me level up the effectiveness of my command line usage.</p> <h3 id="gotchas"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#gotchas" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong>Gotchas</strong></h3> <p>There are two outputs from each command, standard out (stdout) and standard error (stderr). Pipe by default connects to stdout.</p> <h2 id="--aka-dash"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#--aka-dash" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong>- (aka dash)</strong></h2> <p>Some commands take a file name as an argument. In cases where I want to use stdin or stdout. Dash is the answer.</p> <p>I use this alot when I want to read a file from s3 and display it to the console or take the output from a command and write the file to s3.</p> <p>Print file to console: <code>aws s3 cp s3://some-bucket-name/awesome-file.json -</code></p> <h2 id="pbpaste-and-pbcopy"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#pbpaste-and-pbcopy" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong><code>pbpaste</code> and <code>pbcopy</code></strong></h2> <p>These are technically commands as well. They interact with the paste buffer.</p> <p>On mac you can access your paste buffer using the paste-buffer-paste (pbpaste) and paste-buffer-copy (pbcopy) commands. I love how they keep my console clean especially when I have trying to transform a large chunk of text/json</p> <p>Example:</p> <p><code>aws s3 cp s3://some-bucket-name/awesome-file.json - | pbcopy</code></p> <p></p> <h2 id="xargs"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#xargs" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong>xargs</strong></h2> <p>This is technically a command. It is a command that executes commands.</p> <p>It executes a command for every line of input it receives. The arguments you pass to xargs form the basis of the command to execute.</p> <p>Hint: use <code>-J{}</code> to substitute <code>{}</code> (or some other character string) in the middle of the command to execute or multiple times for that matter.</p> <p>Example: <code>pbpaste | xargs -J{} aws s3 cp {} -</code></p> <p></p> <h2 id="2-and-21"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#2-and-21" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong><code>2></code> and <code>2>&1</code></strong></h2> <p>Sometimes I want to send stderr somewhere else other than the console. Using its number is the way.</p> <p>Send to trash: <code>2>/dev/null</code></p> <p>Send to error log: <code>2> error-log.txt</code></p> <p>Combine with stdout: <code>2>&1</code></p> <h2 id="ctl-z--fg"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#ctl-z--fg" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong>Ctl-z + fg</strong></h2> <p>Suspend the foreground process, run some other commands, then return the suspended process to the foreground.</p> <h2 id="man----n"><a aria-hidden="true" href="#man----n" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong>man + / + n</strong></h2> <p>When I know the command but not the exact syntax my first source of information is the manual. Instead of searching google I search the manual.</p> <p>Example: <code>man xargs</code> then <code>/utility</code> advance to next found instance with <code>n</code></p> <p></p> <p></p></div></div></div></div> <section id="subscribe-form" class="subscribe-form wf-section"><div class="centered-container w-container"><h2>Subscribe to posts</h2> <p>Enter your email If you would like to get an email the next time we post.<br>We post about ~1-3x per month, and up to once a month about company news.<br></p></div> <div class="container-5 w-container"><div id="embedded-form"></div></div></section> <div class="banner wf-section"><div class="container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-center"><div class="column desk-12"><img src="/images/Rectangle-240-copy.svg" loading="lazy" alt class="absolute-image"> <div class="cta-box"><div class="text-box _600px"><h2>Launch a hello world</h2> <p>Fork and deploy a hello world project onto Cyclic faster than it has taken to read this page. Experience the power.</p> <div class="spacer _24"></div> <a href="https://app.cyclic.sh/api/login?utm_source=www&utm_medium=web&utm_campaign=cta" target="_blank" class="button white w-button">Deploy on Cyclic </a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div> <div class="footer wf-section"><div class="spacer _64"></div> <div class="footer-container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-top"><div class="column desk-6 tab-12"><a href="/" aria-current="page" data-ix="logo" class="footer-logo w-nav-brand w--current nuxt-link-active"><img src="/images/default-monochrome-white.svg" loading="lazy" alt="cyclic logo" class="image"></a> <p class="paragraph-small no-margin"> 2021-2022 <a href="/" aria-current="page" class="w--current">Cyclic Software</a><br></p> <div class="spacer _64"></div></div> <div class="column desk-2 tab-4 mob-6"></div> <div class="column desk-2 tab-4 mob-6"><div class="footer-links-container"><h5 class="footer-header">Social</h5> <a href="https://github.com/cyclic-software" target="_blank" class="footer-link">Github</a> <a href="https://discord.cyclic.sh" target="_blank" class="footer-link">Discord </a> <a href="https://twitter.com/cyclicsoftware" target="_blank" class="footer-link">Twitter</a></div></div> <div class="column desk-2 tab-4 mob-6"><div class="footer-links-container"><h5 data-w-id="bd6f9588-23b4-f07d-9f3a-b6bd5f4c319c" data-easing="ease" data-easing2="ease" role="banner" class="nav-bar w-nav"><div class="nav-container w-container"><div class="logo-div"><a href="/" class="nav-content w-nav-menu"><div class="nav-menu"><a href="/pricing" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Pricing</a> <a href="/blog" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Blog</a> <a href="https://docs.cyclic.sh/docs/intro" target="_blank" class="nav-link w-nav-link">Docs</a></div> <div class="nav-cta-button-container"><a href="https://app.cyclic.sh/api/login" data-w-id="bd6f9588-23b4-f07d-9f3a-b6bd5f4c31b7" class="nav-link filled w-nav-link">Sign In</a></div></nav> <div class="menu-button w-nav-button"><img src="/images/White-Menu.svg" loading="lazy" width="24" alt class="menu-icon"></div></div></div> <div><div class="section half-padding wf-section"><div class="container w-container"><div class="blog-image-header"><img src="/content/62cc3520191c331e4494f0c7_lambda-pac-man-1600x840.png" alt class="image-cover"></div></div></div> <div class="section small-padding wf-section"><div data-w-id="cb94c0a0-2bab-b0c9-9da8-d93e4ab951f6" xstyle="opacity:0" class="blog-container w-container"><h1>How to Fail at Serverless: Serverless is Stateless</h1> <div class="byline"><div class="text-block-6">By:</div> <div><div class="text-block-6">Kam Lasater</div> <a href="https://twitter.com/@seekayel" class="link-2">@seekayel</a></div> <div class="div-block"></div> <div class="text-block-5">Posted: July 11, 2022</div></div> <div class="div-block-2"><a href="#" class="link-block w-inline-block w-clearfix"><div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div> <div class="html-embed share-button w-embed"></div></a></div> <div class="spacer _32"></div> <div class="rich-text w-richtext"><div class="nuxt-content"><p>This blog series is an extended version of a talk I gave at <a href="https://nyc.serverlessdays.io/" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Serverless Days NYC 2022</a>. The goal is to share ways that a "friend of mine" has failed at serverless to help level up the community. Just as the transportation industry shares accident report analysis with the whole industry to improve safety, we in the software community need to do the same. This is my attempt to do that.</p> <p>I'm sure there is some product X that has feature Y that fixes issue Z. I either didn't know about it at the time, didn't have the budget, couldn't get it through vendor/security review, product wouldnt schedule it with our engineers or it didn't comply with enterprise architecture's plan for our software roadmap. As some guy once said: "You go to production with the tools you have, not the tools you want."</p> <p><strong>Note:</strong> </p> <ul> <li>Names have been changed to protect the innocent and not so innocent.</li> <li>Only egos (and wallets) were harmed by the failures recounted here.</li> </ul> <h2 id="serverless-is-stateless"><a href="#serverless-is-stateless" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Serverless is Stateless</h2> <p>All the architecture posts talk about serverless as stateless computing. How serverless is so scalable because it scales out to satisfy increased load, and scales in when not needed. This all makes sense. Lambda is like a big thread pool in the sky. Got it.</p> <p>I can set some parameters to manage the maximum and minimum number of threads and AWS would handle all the hard work of hosting, spinning up, spinning down and networking the instances together. Awesome-sauce.</p> <p></p> <p><img alt="" src="/content/62c86713fed3b513be122ce8_i-dont-remember.gif"></p> <p>lambda be like</p> <p>Well, almost...</p> <h3 id="use-case"><a href="#use-case" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Use Case</h3> <p>Background job that receives batches (10's-100's) of PDFs from the client, splits them apart into individual pages (1-1000 per PDF) and does analysis on each page. The arrival rate from the client is lumpy. Primarily US working hours on a 5 min interval. Response is measured in hours. This feels like a perfect HelloWorld use case for StepFunctions doing orchestration and Lambda doing image manipulation.</p> <h4 id="lambda-logic"><a href="#lambda-logic" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Lambda logic:</h4> <ul> <li>Invoke with S3 path to file</li> <li>Read 10+mb files from S3 to /tmp</li> <li>Process file</li> <li>Write results to S3</li> <li>Respond with S3 path to transformed file</li> </ul> <p></p> <p>Serverless FTW!</p> <p>Everything works great until... inconsistent out of disk space errors, or no space left on device (depending on your OS/language stack).</p> <h2 id="how-to-fail"><a href="#how-to-fail" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>How to Fail</h2> <h3 id="problem"><a href="#problem" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Problem</h3> <p>Periodically a step function run will fail due to a Lambda invoke failing on no space left on device (or similar depending on os and language). Running the same file in dev/test doesn't reproduce the error. Re-running the step function in production succeeds.</p> <p></p> <p><img alt="" src="/content/62c866a26c2399e457733a1f_lambda-pac-man.png"></p> <p>lambda pac man loves eating data and leaving it in /tmp</p> <h3 id="solution"><a href="#solution" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong>Solution</strong></h3> <p>Well... lambda instances have a writable <code>/tmp</code> folder where you can store temporary files. And somewhere in the AWS docs they describe how instances of your Lambda function are reused between invocations.</p> <p>Some quick googling gets you a solution of clearing <code>/tmp</code> at the start and/or end of each invocation (<a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44108712/aws-lambda-release-tmp-storage-after-each-execution" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">stack overflow ftw</a>). Till that fix makes it to production you can just re-execute any failed step function runs.</p> <p>Nothing quite like shipping code copy-pasted from Stack Overflow. Nice.</p> <p>Success! Party!</p> <p><img alt="" src="/content/62c867cdc310db14bbac6405_leo-congrats.gif"></p> <p>Stack Overflow code FTW!</p> <p></p> <p>until... wait what? out of memory errors? WTF!</p> <h3 id="problem-v2"><a href="#problem-v2" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a><strong>Problem v2</strong></h3> <p>Periodically a step function run fails. The Lambda invoke error is no memory left (or similar depending on os and language). Running the same file in dev/test doesn't reproduce the error. Re-running the step function in production succeeds. Turning on debug or releasing new builds adding additional logging suppress the error rate. WTF (why the failure?) Load tests don't reproduce the error.</p> <p>The explanation that AWS just fails on 1 in ~100k lambda invokes starts to wear thin with your Ops team that is getting paged to click a button. But we could just automate the re-run!</p> <p>Deep inside accepting it "just fails" violates some axiom about how computers works. This is knowable and damn-it I shall know. So you strap the lambda down setting max concurrency to 1. Turn up the load test. Lets do this.</p> <p>At 12k documents the lambda invoke fails for out of memory. Interesting.</p> <p>Rerun the load test. At 12k documents the lambda invoke fails for out of memory.</p> <p>If an error is repeatable it isn't random. 12k is an important number. It also happens to be the maximum number of file descriptors allowed for the linux OS the lambda is running on.</p> <p>Back to google. Apparently the image manipulation library I am using has a history of bugs with leaving open file descriptors. Looks like each invoke to lambda is leaving another file descriptor open in the OS file descriptor table.</p> <p>The lambda will then fail when it hits 12k unless it is recycled. The lambda instance can be recycled due to:</p> <ul> <li> <p>a code deployment: new code, new instances</p> </li> <li> <p>update to environment variable: hence why turning on debugging suppressed errors.</p> </li> <li> <p>scaling down: a burst in load will scale out new instances and then scale back down. Only some instances survive.</p> </li> </ul> <h3 id="solution-v2"><a href="#solution-v2" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>Solution v2</h3> <p>Expand the IAM role permissions to allow the lambda permission to update itself (your security team might give you side eye for this, fair warning, send them this blog post, I'm sure it will convince them).</p> <p>After completing the work of an invoke, call the lambda api to set an environment variable to a random value. We dubbed this the "self-immolation" solution.</p> <p><img alt="" src="/content/62c868256c23997e757361fa_lambda-self-immolation.png"></p> <p>This lambda will self destruct in 3... 2... 1...</p> <p>Hacky? Yeah.</p> <p>Chaos for the lambda team? Probably.</p> <h3 id="yolo-"><a href="#yolo-" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1"><span class="icon icon-link"></span></a>YOLO </h3> <p>Did it work? Yes.</p> <p>Stay tuned, for more stories of #fail.</p></div></div></div></div> <section id="subscribe-form" class="subscribe-form wf-section"><div class="centered-container w-container"><h2>Subscribe to posts</h2> <p>Enter your email If you would like to get an email the next time we post.<br>We post about ~1-3x per month, and up to once a month about company news.<br></p></div> <div class="container-5 w-container"><div id="embedded-form"></div></div></section> <div class="banner wf-section"><div class="container w-container"><div class="_12-columns align-center"><div class="column desk-12"><img src="/images/Rectangle-240-copy.svg" loading="lazy" alt class="absolute-image"> <div class="cta-box"><div class="text-box _600px"><h2>Launch a hello world</h2> <p>Fork and deploy a hello world project onto Cyclic faster than it has taken to read this page.
